title: 109_hr2296
content: The "Guard and Reserve Financial Stability Act of 2005" includes provisions for Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credits under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit equal to 50% of the actual compensation amount or $30,000 for each employee on qualified active duty. The actual compensation amount is the pay for days when the employee is absent for duty. No credit is allowed for days when the employee does not perform qualified duty. The Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit allows small business employers to claim a credit equal to 50% of the actual compensation amount or $30,000 for each employee on qualified active duty. Small business employers are defined as those who employed an average of 50 or fewer employees on business days during the taxable year. All persons treated as a single employer under specific sections shall be considered a single employer. Qualified active duty refers to active duty exceeding 179 days or indefinite periods, entitling employees to reemployment rights. The curr_chunk discusses reemployment rights, benefits, and compensation for employees under specific sections of the United States Code. It defines terms like compensation and Ready Reserve-National Guard employee. Certain rules similar to section 52 apply. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to the Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit. It includes changes to the general business credit and denial of double benefits. Amendment to subpart D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes insertion after section 45I. The amendment includes a new Ready Reserve-National Guard employee credit effective after September 30, 2004. It also introduces a Qualified Replacement Employee credit under section 51(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment introduces a Qualified Replacement Employee credit under section 51(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, defining a qualified replacement employee as an individual hired to replace a Ready Reserve-National Guard employee during their qualified active duty. The term 'eligible taxpayer' refers to a small business employer with 50 or fewer employees on business days during the taxable year. The term 'eligible taxpayer' refers to a small business employer with 50 or fewer employees on business days during the taxable year. Section 414 shall be treated as a single employer. The terms 'Ready Reserve-National Guard employee' and 'qualified active duty' are defined in section 45J(d)(3) and section 45J(d)(1) respectively. Disallowance for failure to comply with employment or reemployment rights of members of the reserve components of the armed forces of the United States results in no credit allowed under subsection (a) for a taxpayer. The tax credit extension applies to an eligible taxpayer under a final order from a district court related to a violation of chapter 43 of title 38 of the United States Code. The credit extension also includes the 2 succeeding taxable years. Additionally, the credit extension is applicable to amounts paid to a qualified replacement employee until December 31, 2006. The amendments made by this subsection apply to amounts paid or incurred to an individual who begins work for the employer after September 30, 2004. The Comptroller General of the United States will study problems in recruiting individuals for a reserve component of the Armed Forces and the effectiveness of the tax credit for hiring and retaining employees in this category. The Comptroller General of the United States will report on any compliance problems in the administration of the tax credit for hiring and retaining employees in the reserve component of the Armed Forces to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee by December 1, 2005.
